bug.author: jejay
bug.summary: TF1 tf.image.resize_image does not work with unbatched variable size image anymore since 1.12
bug.description:
(Sorry for not adhering to the template, I can point to the problematic commit) I use tf.image.resize_images to resize variable sized images in an unbatched manner, like so: <denchmark-code>tf.image.resize_images( tf.reshape(x, [-1, 100, 3]), size, method=tf.image.ResizeMethod.BILINEAR ) </denchmark-code>
I.e. some images are 100x100, some 110x100 etc. Upon updating tensorflow I received the following error: <denchmark-code>Traceback (most recent call last): [...] File "data_preprocess_amass.py", line 32, in __init__ method=tf.image.ResizeMethod.BILINEAR File "/mnt/HDD1/julian/anaconda3/envs/tensorflow/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tensorflow_core/python/ops/image_ops_impl.py", line 1187, in resize_images skip_resize_if_same=True) File "/mnt/HDD1/julian/anaconda3/envs/tensorflow/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tensorflow_core/python/ops/image_ops_impl.py", line 1053, in _resize_images_common new_height_const = size_const_as_shape.dims[0].value TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not subscriptable </denchmark-code>
I investigated it and it seems that the commit <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/commit/f43d458a318d4d97298710654f1692f6e8364f82>f43d458</denchmark-link> is the culprit, introducing the following lines to image_ops_impl.py: <denchmark-code>new_height_const = size_const_as_shape.dims[0].value new_width_const = size_const_as_shape.dims[1].value </denchmark-code>
blame: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blame/r1.15/tensorflow/python/ops/image_ops_impl.py#L1053>https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blame/r1.15/tensorflow/python/ops/image_ops_impl.py#L1053</denchmark-link>
It is included since 1.12.1. Downgrading to 1.11 solved it for me. Might be a very special use case on a already deprecated function but I thought its worth reporting.

comments.comment:
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/jejay>@jejay</denchmark-link>
Request you to share colab link or simple standalone code with supporting files to reproduce the issue in our environment.It helps us in localizing the issue faster. Thanks!
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you.
No wait I'll do it, just give me some time I have a deadline end of the month.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/jejay>@jejay</denchmark-link>
Any update on this issue please. Thanks!

So its basically just the code I already presented: <denchmark-code>import numpy as np import tensorflow as tf
x = tf.placeholder(tf.float32) size = tf.placeholder(tf.int32)
result = tf.image.resize_images(tf.reshape(x, [-1, 100, 3]), size)
session = tf.Session() r = session.run(result, { x: np.random.normal(size=(100, 100, 3)), size: [20, 20] }) </denchmark-code>
works on pre 1.12 and fails afterwards with: <denchmark-code>Traceback (most recent call last): File "py.py", line 10, in <module> method=tf.image.ResizeMethod.BILINEAR) File "[...]/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tensorflow/python/ops/image_ops_impl.py", line 960, in resize_images name=None) File "[...]/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tensorflow/python/ops/image_ops_impl.py", line 1041, in resize_images_v2 new_height_const = size_const_as_shape.dims[0].value TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not subscriptable </denchmark-code>

I have tried in colab and i am not seeing any issue with TF version <= 1.12 and i could reproduce the issue with TF version >1.12.Please,find the gist <denchmark-link:https://colab.sandbox.google.com/gist/ravikyram/f3b22183898179523f0837b637d5ce47/untitled864.ipynb>here</denchmark-link> .Thanks!

The issue was that the line with the error was not v1/v2 TensorShape backwards compatible. It should be fixed at head now. Iâ€™ve <denchmark-link:https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1C9_VBU-dSXnkabBLSUZWveylVQTzcfZK?usp=sharing#scrollTo=8r0M6AQoqXPK>verified</denchmark-link> it with tf-nightly version 2.3.0-dev20200515. On older branches, we unfortunately need to wait until the next patch release to cherrypick it in (note: supported versions are 1.5, 2.0, 2.1, 2.2). If you need to work with TF versions >= 1.13 and <= 2.2, one interim possibility would be to build tf from source with the <denchmark-link:https://github.com/UofT-EcoSystem/tensorflow/commit/24c75ce5016efb4ab107f27b96aac07549d8617b>two liner fix</denchmark-link> .
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/jejay>@jejay</denchmark-link> Closing this issue since it was resolved already. Please feel free to reopen the issue in case of any concern. Thanks!

Are you satisfied with the resolution of your issue? <denchmark-link:https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfaP12TRhd9xSxjXZjcZFNXPGk4kc1-qMdv3gc6bEP90vY1ew/viewform?entry.85265664=Yes&entry.2137816233=https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/38694>Yes</denchmark-link>
